title: INNOVATIVE ways to REDUCE the toxicity.
body:
This is just some insight as to a few more punishments which could significantly reduce repeated offenders who receive chat/time bans on their accounts:

Along with the chat restriction:
1. Wipe their Influence Points to 0. 
This is a great incentive for players with progressive goals to NOT act like savages. If they want new runes or champs via IP, they must start from scratch, or play nice.

2. Influence point restriction included. Summoners may not EARN influence points until they've completed the necessary mandated amount of restricted games. This correlates well with option 1, in that players will be wiped clean and then also restricted for their 10/25/30 game restriction.

  Players who are goal-oriented and care about the game won't be acting up, and the players who DO misbehave are forced to take a much better look at the big picture when it comes to progression in this game. 

I propose ideas that wouldnt effect the monetary income of Riot, out of respect for their business.

If someone is uber toxic and gets their IP wiped and restricted and decides "eff this game im not playing anymore" then that literally weens out the bad vibes in league that much more. 

These are two ideas that ERADICATE trolls and toxicity, without disturbing the popultion of dedicated, loving players.

Thanks for reading, please comment your thoughts or tweaks to this if you have any suggestions!

replies.body: I understand the intention, but honestly I think it would make people more likely to quit than reform. Who wants to grind 25 games just to continue grinding for the champion you want?  I understand some people are just too determined to not quit, but the people that are toxic, you know, they don't really enjoy the game much.

But honestly there's no incentive for reform right now... At all. If you're gonna troll and be a dick, and you wont accwpt a ten game IP suspension without quitting... Then good riddence honestly. That's one less toxic player in the game.

THATS THE POINT.

The problem is toxic players just get put in timeout until there's an open window to be toxic again. They aren't truly penalized. They cant type, but no matter how toxic they are, theyre still being rewarded. That, in my opinion, is wrong.

The incentive to reform is to protect your account from getting banned. Most people DO reform, because they don't have a bunch of time/boat loads of money to get a new account back to the status their current account is.

if a player would quit over a ten game influence point suspension, they dont HAVE the incentive to reform and continue playing in the first place.

That's the point.

The slap on the wrist that is a "chat ban" doesnt actually make it clear to the offender that they've done something bad.

Most players just keep getting chat ban after chat ban until theyre perm banned, then you see them post on this forum being like "THIS DOESNT DESERVE A BAN" meanwhile it clearly does, and the player never believed they did anything significantly punishable because they were never truly punished at all until the perm ban.

Does that make more sense?

That's not an argument for the system. If it's not helping those people reform, there is no reason to implement it. Also, I disagree with that statement. There's a difference between not using the chat feature and not being able to collect the champions you want to play.

Okay i can agree with the first part of the statement. Maybe it doesnt help players reform

But being a bad influence on the game and community as a whole, should definitely not allow you to collect and achieve at the same rate of people who can play the game civilly.

While I don't really agree with that sentiment, I think there's a better way to do it.

>This explanation is here if you don't know how the report system works. If you do skip it. 

>When someone reports you, the chat log is sent to Riot, and the automatic system will scan the chat log for key phrases and use other measures to determine whether the report is valid. If it is valid, you then get a mark on your record. This happens almost immediately, usually before you leave the lobby, which is why you get so many reported people saying "Judged? Nobody from Riot even read this".

 If you receive a validated report, take a percentage of IP away you earned that game away. It plays into the immediate feedback, so you understand that you did something wrong, and it doesn't punish you for just playing the game.

Interesting idea. I like that you gave this thought. 

Honestly, i just bring this topic up because toxicity impacts almost every single game ive played in this week.

Its not even about people saying mean things, its that i cant win a game where my teammates are playing against each other.

So long as Riot continues to use the 'permanent banning' system, where they falsely claim that "only 0.06% of players are permanently banned", I don't see the toxicity of League's community getting better.

Riot's done a good job of falsifying stats, especially Pendragon, but their numbers simply don't add up. It's estimated that more than 70% of League's community has been chat restricted or banned at some point.

What they need to do is throw away this Accumulative-to-Permanent banning system. It's common knowledge it doesn't work, people will just make new accounts and continue to be toxic.

Well if you don't see it getting better, i dont see why uncaging the zoo animals entirely will help at all. Please explain what you mean by "throw out the system"

Do you think it should be thrown out completely, with no bans at all? Or should it be replaced with something indefinitely?

Permanent Bans are what needs to be thrown out. It's not a good solution, in fact, that solution alone is counter-intuitive and promotes toxicity.

League of Legends is the **only** online game that has permanent bans, and coincidentally, they're the only game that is reputed as having the most toxic community.

Look, someone who doesn't know jack about correlation vs causality.
Hey, guess what?
Having permanent bans doesn't make people toxic.
People are toxic, hence they get permabanned.

> [{quoted}](name=Sir Hammerlock,realm=NA,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=AAvOQBKp,comment-id=000300000000,timestamp=2016-05-16T07:42:18.427+0000)
>
> Permanent Bans are what needs to be thrown out. It's not a good solution, in fact, that solution alone is counter-intuitive and promotes toxicity.

Where's your proof that permabans promote toxicity? If anything they help to get rid of toxicity by forcing players who would otherwise just continue to misbehave to go away (i.e. shape up or ship out).

> League of Legends is the **only** online game that has permanent bans, and coincidentally, they're the only game that is reputed as having the most toxic community.

LoL is certainly not the only game that does permabans, and if you think that they are then you must not have played that many online games.
Thank you for your response. I agree, it's an ironic correlation.

Every company lies about things like this. Most manufacturers lie about their warranty rates, because they keep it artificially low.

I'm sure if you count every single account that's been played, it's correct. But all those banned botted accounts that never typed a word really shouldn't count, should they?

My main of 3000+ games was banned this season for under 10 games worth of play with no racism or homophobia, with nearly 300 games played this season. I'm 100% sure they'll realize they've way over stepped.

Imagine a system where you can potentially be so well-behaved that you earn vouchers for % off your next purchase, or a flat rate of discount of IP prices due to having a pristine record of good behavior. Even the slightest anything would incentivize this system.

Right? I feel the same way. Literally, there is no incentive to act decently and there's no punishment for acting a fool. Players who are banned still receive influence points from the game they got flagged in! At the very least, they shouldn't earn influence points for being bad enough of an influence to get penalized. It's so ironic.

I agree with this.
however if riot had a more effective report system this might work, with what we currently have this not only would not work but would possibly punish innocent players being dogpiled by reports via trolls and such.

I'm not saying it happens all the time but plenty of time I've seen troll premades dogpiling someone with reports for simply not playing the game how they want them to.

I personally like it, great idea. Maybe more/longer chat retricts or the outright removal of chat if toxicity persists. Then if they feed after that ban them. Quicker punishments for feed/afk in addition.
Yea i think this would work - only one problem. After a certain point (maybe lvl 30) you don't really need ip. If u have your mains you can just play without problems

Of course. I thought of that too.

this is why i didnt suggest penalties that would cost Riot money (RP/Store bans on timers) or anything like that

Im sure the demographic of player who doesnt need IP isnt as toxic as the demographic of player that DOES need IP, however.

there will always be exceptions, although i think this is a bonus tack that will help newer players who want to learn, and get stuck with new players who think theyre challenger in bronze division then act like trashbags to their teammates. 

Trust me, there's a lot of distorted thinking amongst new players / low elo players which cause them to act NAIVE AS WELL AS TOXIC. 

I grow less toxic myself in correlation to my experience and understanding of the game. The more i understand and earn, the more i understand that NOT EVERYONE understands everything. Understand?

The problem I see with this is that a lot of things that can be bought with IP, can also be bought with RP. This punishment would effectively hurt their paying customers less than their non-paying ones, and I really don't think that's a good idea.

replies.body:
Riot encourages toxicity. Nobody is looking between the lines here. They are even happier to ban people so quickly. 

Do you really know WHY riot changed the EXP it took to 30? Do you really believe what they said about it? Smart people don't. It is too obvious that Riot has been perma banning people pretty quickly this season and COINCIDENTALLY made EXP to 30 by half. It's a business decision on their part. They know that a high % of people who get perma banned will make a new account and MOST likely buy boosts/champs/skins all over again. Do you guys really not see this? 

You may ask why RIOT doesn't double the EXP it took to 30? Well then that will get them to lose money compared to halving the exp. I really would think that doubling the EXP to 30 would discourage toxicity...I mean...who really wants to spend weeks/months leveling up again. People will think TWICE about their behavior. 

They careless about newbies. New people don't even care to rush to 30. Only people that do this are smurfs so they can jump into ranked. New people don't even know much about Ranked or even the game play. 

This entire process was to benefit from toxic people and increase their revenue. It takes 3 days to hit 30 if you play a lot of hours during those 3 days. You can start on Friday and hit 30 by Sunday night. But exp boosts and an ip boost and boom, new account, new MMR, ready to go for ranked. That's just 20 bucks! That's not including people who dont mind spending extra on their MAIN champs and possibly skins.

They say they wanna 'cater' to new players. Don't believe that bullshit.

I've met a LOT of new players to LoL...none of them give a damn about leveling up, runes or ranked. They have fun trying new champs and playing and learning and getting to know the game.

So, you are saying they are increasing toxicity for the sake of losing money?
Because that's what you are basically saying. Permabanned players are a tiny tiny fraction of the player base. Getting a bit of extra cash from them, but undermining the enjoyment of their own game, effectively lowering the willingness to spend money on the game for **everybody** will effectively cost them money.

At first glance your idea might seem logical... but you know what sounds logical at first **and** second glance to everybody that is not paranoid? Their explanation, which you simply toss aside by saying "Don't believe that bullshit" and personal anecdotes, which btw, I can counter with my own anecdotes of people that stopped playing the game because they felt it was too much of a grind until you were out of the fairly bad pre-30 matchmaking.

I love you.

This is well written and logical.

You're right. It does not help the community be less toxic by insta-boosting to 30 and throwing day 4 players in the same games as season 1-5 veterans.

In fact, that does indeed promote toxicity

Thank you for your insight

I bet DARPA asked for a sample of your skull for bulletproofing.

We need to give Influence Points a literal meaning. Experience Points are a measurement of your experience in leveling through the game. That's literal. Influence points should be somewhat measured on a summoner's INFLUENCE on the game. If you are a bad influence, your influence points should be impacted. If you're a good or neutral influence, you may earn and spend them as you may.

This ensures that toxic players dont get free things for their misconduct! If they want it, they must pay for it through RP until their restriction is over
